results.title: Mischief
results.creator_credit: Ian Shand, Jack Grossman and Children's Film Foundation
results.brief_description: At a village pony auction a Davey misses out on buying a pony which was purchased by the owner of a pony trekking stable. He gets a job at the stable looking after the pony ‘Mischief’ leading to the jealousy of other stable hands and his eventual wrongful sacking. When another young boy visiting the stable is thrown from the pony onto a quarry ledge, Davey and ‘Mischief’ try to rescue him before blasting commences at the quarry. Stars: Paul Frazer, Iain Burton, Adrianne Byrne, Michael Newport, Gina Malcolm, Gerald Sim, Colin Gordon, Bill Owen, Frieda Knorr, Charles Rea, Peter Porteous, Deidre Benner and Gerald Williams.

results.title: Mars attacks the world
results.creator_credit: Ford Beebe, Robert F Hill, Barney A Sarecky and Filmcraft Production
results.brief_description: Based on Alex Raymond’s newspaper feature “Flash Gordon” and the serial “Flash Gordon’s trip to Mars”, this condensed version of the serial provides a fascinating historical look into the sci-fi films of the past, minus all the special effects and computer animation of today’s blockbuster sci-fi films. The story revolves around the universal theme of good vs evil, of enemy planets trying to destroy Earth. When strange unexplained phenomena start occuring on Earth, Flash Gordon (Larry “Buster” Crabbe), Dr Zarkov (Frank Shannon) and Dale Arden (Jean Rogers) jump to the rescue and take a space flight to Mars, crash-landing in the Valley of Desolation. There Flash runs into his old enemy Ming the Merciless of Planet Mongo, and Ming’s ally, Queen Azura of Mars, whose attempts to destroy Earth with a deadly ray are eventually thwarted by Flash and his companions with the help of The Clay King and his Clay Men. Flash, Dale and Dr Zarkov return to Earth to a hero’s welcome, ticker-tape parade and all. Cast also includes Charles Middleton, Beatrice Roberts, Donald Kerr, Richard Alexander. NB: “Due to unique material contained herein, fluctuations may occur in picture and sound quality.”

results.title: Married Life
results.creator_credit: C.J. Andrews, V. G. Jones and London Filmmaker's Co-op
results.brief_description: A naturalistic approach to experimental film making. The filmmakers have taken one script and interpreted it in four different ways.

results.title: On the border of life: glimpses of French biological research
results.creator_credit: Jean Rostand, Nicole Vedres, Jacqueline Jacoupy and Triangle Productions
results.brief_description: Opens with brief introductions to biology, and then surveys the work of leading French laboratories. The ground covered includes experiments in artificial parthenogenesis, sex determination, suspended animation and research into the secrets of immortality. Commentary by John Barry.

results.title: On the Black Hill
results.creator_credit: Andrew Grieve, Jennifer Howarth and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Bruce Chatwin, this is an unrelenting portrayal of the raw experience of rural farm life in the Welsh border country. Starting in 1895, it focuses on the lives of four generations of a farming community and spans 85 years. At the heart of the story is the intense relationship between identical twin brothers, Benjamin (Mike Gwilym) and Lewis (Robert Gwilym) Jones. The film ultimately expresses the healing nature of time and the promise of the future.

results.title: On target marketing: retailing and services; manufacturing
results.creator_credit: Paul Humfress, Tony Coyte and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Marketing techniques are described and illustrated through a sequence of case studies which show how successful small business owners developed a marketing strategy which contributed to the growth and increased profitability of their businesses. This program takes examples of small businesses from the manufacturing, retail and service sectors.

results.title: On stage please at Hackney Empire
results.creator_credit: David E. Naughton, David L. Watkins and David E Naughton Film and Television Productions
results.brief_description: An historical account of one of Britain’s last-standing music hall theatres, the Hackney Empire. Opened in 1901 this wonderful theatre became the home for many famous British music hall artists and entertainers right up into the 1950s when it was finally closed down in 1956. However, against all odds, the music theatre has survived and this film documents the re-opening in 1989 with interviews, personal reminiscings, stills, archival footage and live performances from past and present entertainers including Bernard Bresslaw, Roy Hudd, Chas ‘n’ Dave, Helen shapiro, Frankie Vaughan, Tommy Trinder, Barbara Windsor, Larry Adler and many more. Also features the Royal Artillery Orchestra. Variety at its best.

results.title: Mischa
results.creator_credit: David Vaisbord, Jennifer Torrance and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Director David Vaisbord allows to viewer to share his search to unravel the mystery of his enigmatic Uncle, the violinist Mischa Weisbord. In his prime Mischa was synonymous with fine music, performing throughout Europe and America at the most prestigious venues. In later life Mischa faded into obscurity, a shadow of his former self. When he died he died in poverty, his body laying undiscovered for days because of his reclusive nature. David Vaisbord attempts to reconcile Mischa’s tragic ending to his prolific youth by travelling throughout Europe, Russia, Israel and New York, speaking to family, friends and admirers of the famous musician.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Vaisbord, Jennifer Torrance and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Miscarriage
results.brief_description: Miscarriage is an extremely common event but for many women it is an unexpected shock from which they may take many years to recover. The sense of failure and feelings of guilt often experienced after a miscarriage can have devastating and influential roles on lives and marriages. This film, co-written by G.P. Dr. Anne McPherson, and sociologist, Ann Oakley, sets out to de-mystify miscarriage through the experiences of women who have had one.

results.title: Mirror image = Ming dai zhui zhu
results.creator_credit: Hsiao Ya-chuan, Hsien Ping Han, Asiatic Films, Chang Shu A&V Production, Lumen Films and Sinomovie
results.brief_description: After his father has a stroke, Tung-chin (Lee Jiunn-Jye) finds himself in charge of the family business, a pawnshop. He is kept company by his girlfriend Eiko, a woman he met on the Internet when he went by the name of “No-line”, the origins of which are revealed: 3 months ago he fell from his scooter, scarring his hand and removing all traces of lines. He now considers himself free from the fate life has dealt him and dictated by circumstance. Eiko is determined to recover an image of his palm and restore his future. The majority of the film takes place in the shop, the couple’s ennui punctuated by card playing, dancing, and reading the palms of their customers once they manage to convince them that it’s a legal requirement. No-line meets a woman called I Know and they begin travelling the subway together hocking items from the store. A collaborator of Hou Hsiao-Hsien, Hsiao Ya-chuan’s feature film debut gestures to Wong Kar-Wai and is a quirky tale of limited locales about manipulation, fate and the inability to avoid it. Satisfying in visuals rather than in the content it is exploring, the film was well received by critics in the Taipai Film Festival (2000) and Vancouver International Film Festival (2001): the director considered one of Taiwan’s emerging talents. Executive producers: Hou Hsiao-hsien, Hwrng Wern-Ying. In Mandarin and Taiwanese with English subtitles.
